Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer's decision was unreasonable due to insufficient consideration of new evidence
Application_Facts: Applicant provided a September 2002 UNHCR Report that contained new evidence relevant to their PRRA application
Court_Ruling: The PRRA officer's decision was made in reviewable error; case referred back for redetermination
Claimant_Status: Applicant whose refugee claim was previously rejected
Defendant_Behavior: PRRA officer failed to adequately consider or reference significant new evidence in decision
Grounds_for_Claim: New evidence (UNHCR report) arose after initial rejection and was not reasonably available earlier
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decisions under IRPA
Assessment_Factor: Probative value of the new UNHCR report
Procedural_Issue: Failure to mention and assess new evidence in written decision
Application_Basis: PRRA application based on new evidence
Relief_Sought: Redetermination of PRRA application by a different officer
Governing_Rule: Under IRPA s.113(a), only new evidence that arose after the rejection or was not reasonably available can be considered in a PRRA application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA officer did not reference the UNHCR report in the decision despite claiming to have considered it
Outcome: Case referred to a different PRRA officer for reassessment
Harm_Assessment: Risk of unfair determination due to inadequate consideration of evidence relevant to persecution risk
Cause_Description: Applicant's refugee claim was rejected, leading to a PRRA application based on new evidence
Evidence_Handling: Insufficient consideration and documentation of new evidence in decision reasoning
Evidence_Issues: Failure to properly address and analyze newly submitted evidence with significant probative value
Evidence_Assessment: The UNHCR report had significant probative value but was not meaningfully discussed in the decision
Decision_Rationale: Decision found to be unreasonable due to lack of transparent engagement with key evidence
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of explicit discussion of new evidence in decision
